botanical_details.genus: Malus are small to medium-sized deciduous trees with showy flowers in spring and ornamental or edible fruit in autumn; some have good autumn foliage colour

how_to_grow.cultivation: Prefers deep, fertile, moist but well-drained, neutral soil in a sunny, sheltered position. Will not thrive on very acid soils, shallow chalk soils or with shade for more than half the day. May require fruit thinning to improve fruit size and quality. See apple cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by chip budding in late summer, or grafting in mid-winter. Plants grown from pips are unlikely to resemble the parent
how_to_grow.pruning: Prune according to chosen training method. See apple pruning
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphids, including rosy apple aphid and woolly aphid, fruit tree red spider mite, codling moth and other caterpillars
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to apple canker, blossom wilt, brown rot, fireblight, honey fungus and powdery mildews. Has some resistance to apple scab
